description.narrative:
Bridging the Gaps is alliance of nine international organisations and networks and more than 80 local and regional organisations, working towards the end of the AIDS epidemic among key populations.
Supported by global and regional level work, Bridging the Gaps works with over 80 partner organisations in 15 countries in three regions: • Sub-Sahara Africa: Botswana, Kenya, Mozambique, South Africa, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zimbabwe. • South East Asia: Indonesia, Myanmar, Nepal, Vietnam. • Eastern Europe and Central Asia: Georgia, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Ukraine.
In Vietnam, the programme works with, and for the health and human rights of, sex workers and LGBT people, including those living with HIV.

Bridging the Gaps partners in Vietnam work towards ending AIDS among key populations through (1) a strengthened civil society that holds government to account; (2) increased fulfilment of human rights of key populations; and (3) increased SRHR and fewer infections.
Sex workers and LGBT people

Vietnam was the first country in Asia to endorse the UNAIDS target of 90-90-90, and it is making concerted plans to reach this target (90% will know their HIV status, 90% will receive ART, and 90% will experience viral suppression) and to end the HIV epidemic by 2030. To do so effectively, sex workers and LGBT people should not be left behind. The HIV epidemic in the country is concentrated in a number of key populations: people who inject drugs (PWID), female sex workers (FWS), and men who have sex with men (MSM). Many of these populations overlap. HIV infection has been identified in all of Vietnam’s 63 provinces and cities and the total known number of people living with HIV (PLHIV) in Vietnam is 227,154, while there were 85,194 people living with AIDS in 2015. The actual number of infections may be larger, since a significant number of people at-risk and vulnerable to HIV are not tested. It is estimated, though, that at least 80% of those infected know their status. The proportion of female HIV cases among all cases reported has been steadily increasing, from around 10% of infections in the early 1990s to 35% of all infections in 2015. One of the major barriers is the Law on Health Insurance and the decrees and circulars 16, 17, 18, which removed the diagnosis and treatment of HIV from the list of exceptions and exclusions from health insurance coverage. Although coverage is still partial, many key populations are unable to obtain health insurance due to a number of administrative requirements.

sector.narrative: Bridging the Gaps: Vietnam Human rights
Bridging the Gaps: Vietnam STD control including HIV/AIDS
Bridging the Gaps: Vietnam Social mitigation of HIV/AIDS

title.narrative: 5 Human Rights violation cases acted on

description.narrative: Human rights violation cases acted on is the number of violations documented and in the process of being acted on, instead of responded to, meaning that the cases are taken further than documentation, for example reporting, providing psychosocial and or paralegal or legal support.

title.narrative: 5 # human rights violation cases acted on

description.narrative: 5 # human rights violation cases acted on. This is the number of violations documented and in the process of being acted on, instead of ‘responded to’, meaning that the cases are taken further than documentation, for example reporting, providing psychosocial and or paralegal or legal support.

title.narrative: 3 Law enforcement staff trained on human rights

description.narrative: Law enforcement staff trained on human rights is measured by the number of law enforcement staff trained on human rights.

title.narrative: 3 # law enforcement staff trained on human rights

description.narrative: 3 # law enforcement staff trained on human rights

title.narrative: 6 Global level advocacy tools campaigns and resources developed

description.narrative: Number of Global level advocacy tools campaigns and resources developed

title.narrative: 6 # of global-level advocacy tools, campaigns and resources

description.narrative: 6 # of global-level advocacy tools, campaigns and resources. Number of tools campaigns or resources developed

title.narrative: 4 Participation of partner organization in or organization of local

description.narrative: Participation of partner organization in or organization of local national regional or global stakeholder meetings is measured by the number of partner organisations that participate in meetings. Meetings are defined as advocacy meetings with local national regional or global stakeholders.

title.narrative: 4 # partner organisations that participated in or organized local/national/regional/global stakeholder meetings

description.narrative: 4 # partner organisations that participated in or organized local/national/regional/global stakeholder meetings is measured by the number of partner organisations. Meetings are advocacy meetings with local/national/regional/global stakeholders.

title.narrative: 1 Service provision to Key Population Members

description.narrative: Service provision to key population members measures the number of services used by key population members. This is done through 6 indicators that respectively measure the number of testing services, treatment services, PWUD specific medical harm reduction services, other health services meaning condom distribution, social services and legal support services used by key population members.

title.narrative: 1A # of KP members using testing services

description.narrative: 1A # of KP members using testing services (disaggregated by age) everything falling under voluntary counselling and testing is part of this indicator, testing for TB, STIs Age group 24 and under

title.narrative: 1B # of KP members using treatment services

description.narrative: 1B # of KP members using treatment services (disaggregated by age) ART, STI and TB treatment. Age group 25 and above

title.narrative: 1C # of KP members using PWUD specific medical harm reduction services

description.narrative: 1C # of KP members using PWUD specific medical harm reduction services (disaggregated by age) including needle exchange, OST, OD prevention, PWUD specific counselling. Age group 25 and above

title.narrative: 1D # of KP members using other health services (condom distribution)

description.narrative: 1D # of KP members using other health services (disaggregated by age) (condom distribution). Age group 25 and above

title.narrative: 1E # of KP members using social services

description.narrative: 1E # of KP members using social services (disaggregated by age) including self-help groups, psychosocial support, health education and promotion, online counselling, NOT the counselling part of VCT services. Age group 25 and above

title.narrative: 1F # of KP members using legal support services

description.narrative: 1F # of KP members using legal support services (disaggregated by age). Age group 25 and above

Trained service providers is measured through 2 indicators. The first measures the number of service providers trained. Service providers provide social services, including psychosocial support, health education and promotion, online counselling, or health NGO or public sector services. The counselling part of VCT services is excluded. They are individuals within local partner organisations within BtG that provide services, as well as from indirect service providers that receive training from BtG local partners for instance other NGO-run clinics, private clinics, state-run services, etc. The second measures the number of legal service providers trained including paralegal services

2A # of service providers trained. This is the number of individual service providers meaning staff members, trained by alliance partner and/or by a country partner. Total # is the number of people trained by alliance partner and number of people trained by partners. Service providers provide social (including psychosocial support, health education and promotion, online counselling, NOT the counselling part of VCT services), or health(NGO or public sector) services. They are individuals within local partner organisations within BtG that provide services, as well as from indirect service providers that receive training from BtG local partners (e.g. other NGO-run clinics, private clinics, state-run services, etc).
2B # legal service providers trained including paralegal services
